mainmatter.p: An object of the Kleisli category of a monad can be considered as a free algebra, but equipped with a canonical choice of generators. Hence although the Kleisli category is equivalent to the category of free algebras, the objects are essentially different. This manifests as the curious fact that the Kleisli category is not univalent, since an equality of Kleisli objects requires an isomorphism of the generators, but an isomorphism only requires the two free algebras to be isomorphic.

frontmatter.title: The Kleisli category is equivalent to the category of free algebras

mainmatter.p: Given category \mathcal { C }, the Kleisli category of a monad M : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { C } is equivalent to the full subcategory of the M-algebras spanned by the free algebras.
Consider the functor from the Kleisli category to the category of free algebras, sending X to the free algebra on X. This is fully faithful and surjective on objects.

frontmatter.title: The Kleisli category of a monad

mainmatter.p: Given a monad M : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { C } and two objects X, Y in \mathcal { C }, a Kleisli arrow from X to Y is simply any arrow X \to MY. This represents an algebra homomorphism from the free algebra generated by X to that of Y.

The identity Kleisli arrow is defined as \eta : X \to MX. The composition of f : X \to MY and g : Y \to MZ is given by X \xrightarrow {f} MY \xrightarrow {Mg} M^2 Z \xrightarrow { \mu } MZ. This forms a category whose objects are the objects of \mathcal { C }, as a formal symbol standing for the free algebra generated by those objects, and morphisms are Kleisli arrows. This is the Kleisli category \mathcal { C } _M.

Given a monad M on a category \mathcal { C }, there is a canonical adjunction between the category of algebras \mathcal { C } ^M and \mathcal { C }. The forgetful functor U_M takes an algebra and forgets the algebra structure. The free functor F_M takes an object X and produces an algebra on MX given by the monad multiplication map \mu : M^2 X \to MX, called the free algebra.

We just have to verify that the two conversions are mutual inverses. In one way, we need to verify \alpha _Y \circ M f \circ \eta = f. This is true because by the naturality of \eta we get M f \circ \eta = \eta \circ f. Then by the definition of algebra \alpha _Y \circ \eta = \operatorname {id}, proving the equality. On the other hand, we need to show \alpha _Y \circ M( \varphi \circ \eta ) = \varphi. This follows from the algebra identity \alpha _Y \circ M \alpha _Y = \alpha _Y \circ \mu and the monad identity \mu \circ M \eta = \operatorname {id}.

An algebraic cellular complex (or ACC) is a chain complex of free abelian groups. The generators are called cells, and the boundary maps can be expressed using the generators as a basis, yielding the incidence matrices.

More precisely, we may define an ACC as a sequence of sets C_ \bullet, with a sequence of functions d : C_k \to \mathbb {Z}[C_{k-1}], such that d^2 = 0 is satisfied. When a generator has non-zero coefficient in some d \sigma, the generator is called a face of \sigma.
Note that the generators of these chain groups are canonically chosen as part of the data. So a more accurate definition is a chain complex in the Kleisli category of abelian groups.
